course.subject: ISOM
course.name: Decision Analytics
course.description: This course helps the students develop better analytical skills in approaching strategic and tactical business decisions. Students will learn to derive solutions or conclusions that require critical thinking, quantitative analysis, and statistical reasoning skills. These skills are essential and indispensable for major business decisions.
course.prerequisites: ISOM 2500 AND ISOM 2700

reviews.author: Cloud
reviews.comment_content:
Decision Tree
Value of Information
Linear Programming
Markov Chain
Game Theory
Static Game
Dynamic Game
ANOVA

Rich Contents, Interesting topics elaborated in a simple way [She tried to deliver the materials in a way that everyone can understand, so basically not much statistics, but tactics]

You can see that she spent a lot of time in developing the notes and materials
reviews.comment_teaching:
This is the first time she teaches this course, so we are kind of lab rat...

Sometimes she might mix up some of the concepts in class, but she will clarify them right after class.

And if you don't understand the concept in class, better drop her an email or ask her in person, she could explain way better than in class (even better if you speak Mandarin).

Better ask for more comments about your project, she will be very happy to help you!
reviews.comment_grading:
Final 40%
Project  [presentation + report] 30%
4 Cases assignment 30%
Peer evaluation

Cases all full mark
No final / project score

For cases in every stage, you can choose to do one / all of them, they only count the highest one. But we all have similar marks, so your grade mainly depends on the project & final.

For the final, she kind of overestimated us by giving 2 hours for 9 LQ final, and I am pretty sure that no one finished the whole paper...

She didn't release any project / final score, so I can't comment a lot on grading

But I got an A at last
reviews.comment_workload:
I would say the workload is fair, no midterm but 4 cases + project + presentation.

Cases are relatively easy
For the project, it depends on your teammates
For final, better to start revision earlier, because you have to review everything in the course

reviews.author: Dannychoi
reviews.comment_content:
I took the online class for Man Yu
Her lectures were quite interesting and she is quite passionate in teaching.

She provides a lot of practice questions and explains how to do them in lectures.

Course demands:
- 2 small assignments
- 2 big assignments
- Presentation
- Report
- Final exam

Overall quite a demanding course with a lot of content and requires a bit of revising.
reviews.comment_teaching:
She was great at teaching and was really helpful.
If you ask any questions she will answer with great enthusiasm.
Very enjoyable to attend her lectures (but could be a little boring at times because of content)
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading is just average the normal way everyone would grade.
Her exam is quite reasonable, but when I took her online exam, all the questions weren't hard but the time constraint was pretty tough. She isn't the kind of professor that is trying to trick everyone, she seems like she actually wants her students to learn.
reviews.comment_workload: For me this was quite a demanding course, it doesn't have a quiz or anything like other really demanding courses, but this really depends on finding good group mates to work through all the assignments and the report / presentation with.

reviews.author: cwyyy
reviews.comment_content:
Basic quantitative techniques to assist your decision-making. The topics are easy to understand and practical.
1. Decision Tree
2. Value of Information
3. Stochastic Linear Programming
4. Markov Processes
5. Game Theory (Static Games, Mixed Strategies, Dynamic Games, Strategic Moves)
6. Statistical Analysis (Mostly use Excel)

Many examples are used to illustrate the concepts.
reviews.comment_teaching:
She is a nice professor and the lectures are easy to understand. Although she is a Mainland professor, she does not have much accent so there's no difficulty in understanding the material.
I think she devoted much time in making the lecture slides. Calculation steps are listed clearly so that you can follow easily during your own revision time. Sometimes she left out some blanks in the slide and you needed to jot down the answers in class, but you can still catch up with the lecture recordings.
She also gave us a lot of practice problems for us to complete outside class.
You can always reach her easily outside class. She is willing to stay behind to answer your questions and replies emails quite quickly. You can also arrange a consultation meeting about course materials or project with her anytime.
reviews.comment_grading:
Case Studies (30%)
Term Project (30%)
Comprehensive Final Exam (40%)

Full mark for case studies. Scores for project and final are not released.
I finished all the practice problems, missed 1 question in the final, but still got an A. Very good grading in my opinion.
reviews.comment_workload:
Case Studies: Choose 1 among 2 cases for the 4 topics (Decision Tree, Value of Information, Game Theory, Statistical Analysis) The cases are pretty long to read, but the calculation methods are simple. Just stick to what you have learnt in class. Done in group basis so better find some responsible groupmates.

Term Project: Choose 1 of the 6 topics and apply the course concepts and tools (Excel). The most tedious part is finding sufficient and appropriate data for calculation. Calculation part should not be very challenging. Record a <25-min presentation video (Showing ppt slides with your narration in the video) and upload to Canvas at last. No live presentation is required.

Final Exam: Open-book. 8 questions to be completed within 2 hours, which is quite demanding. I'm sure no one can finish the entire exam. I don't think the questions are tricky but do pay attention to what the number represents (especially for calculation in game theory). The practice problems are helpful for you to prepare the exam. Don't forget that the lecture slides also cover many problems. You may also want to review them.

The workload is not demanding as a 3000-level course.

reviews.author: ridiculousism
reviews.comment_content:
The content of this course is learning different tools for decision making. The course is clearly divided into 3 sessions. The first part is Decision Making Under Uncertainty. It is kind of a review of decision tree, LP model and Markov Process, which are relatively easy to understand. The second part is Strategic and Interactive Decision Making, which is mainly about Game Theory. It is still not very hard since Man Yu teaches us to use shortcut to get the solutions. The third part is Statistical Decision Making. This is the most sophisticated part in the course because some statistical knowledge are required. Yet, the good news is you don't really need a 100% understanding to the concept as long as you are familiar with the way to answer questions.

Other than the prerequisite of ISOM2500 and ISOM2700, I believe taking ISOM3710 in advance also helps since Data Analysis and Solver functions in excel are used in this course.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Man Yu explains the analytical tools clearly and it is easy to follow. Although she may overrun sometimes, she lets students go and she will stay behind for further questions. She also leaves some after-class exercise for us to practice and posts the answers on Canvas afterwards.

Her accent is acceptable and you won't get confused on what she talks about. She is patient to students and answers enquiries immediately whenever you raise a question. She also replies emails efficiently.
reviews.comment_grading:
The course consists of 3 components: 4 Case Studies (30%), Team Project (30%), and Comprehensive Final Exam (40%).

Cases: almost full marks
Project presentation: 9.1/10
Project report: 9.3/10
Final exam: 52/80

I am surprised to get an A+ ultimately because intuitively I perform not very well in both the project and exam. I don't have any statistics for the above, but perhaps others are not performing well too.
reviews.comment_workload:
The case studies are easy and they are just some after-class exercises for every section. You only need to work with your groupmates and submit 1 answer per group.

For the team project, you can either choose to think of a decision problem and apply the tools learnt from the course, or further investigate in the tools learnt or new tools. You may need some extra research to support your ideas.

The final exam is open-book and open-note, while it is quite difficult and with inadequate time to complete. We got 120 minutes to answer 9 questions. Most questions are with long background information and sub-questions, and some questions are tricky and really require deep understanding of the concepts.

reviews.author: Dea
reviews.title: The best introductory course to data mining!
reviews.comment_content:
Lecture: I have found that coding is not my forte, however from past internship experience I know that there will be an increasing intersection between business and data mining, so this course is just /perfect/ to get the idea behind data mining, even though it doesn't dig dip into coding with python.

Lab: The TA walked us through generating decision trees etc in Python, and although we were basically given the code and only had to change bits of the code, she explained the 'why's quite well.
reviews.comment_teaching: I quite like the professor! He prepared his presentations well. There was no textbooks. Just jot down whatever he said and took the time to understand the lecture materials, and I think you should do pretty well on the exams. Don't be afraid to ask! Both the professor & the TA should be plenty helpful.
reviews.comment_grading: I can't remember my grades, but I got above B I think! If you study well, you shouldn't be having much problems. Good luck guys.
reviews.comment_workload: The bulk of the work (outside of mid and final) is the group project where you have to code! I got very lucky that two of my groupmates are practically experts in Python and R, so that helps a lot, they basically carry the group :") But if you don't get as lucky as I am, just consult to the TA a lot to make sure that you are heading in the right direction

reviews.author: sharon tse
reviews.comment_content:
See the syllabus.
In summary: rich content! Quite a lot of decision analytics tool covered, and focuses on the basic application only. Won't dig deep into the details or advanced application.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Excellent teacher! Her teaching is passionate. And she explains concept very clearly.

Since this is a new course, professor prepared the course from scratch, and she really took care of the problem of designing the course : although this is an OM course, both IS and OM (or even other major) students take this to fulfill graduation option requirement, and the different statistics background challenge the professor - the course can't have too much statistics (too hard for non-OM / maths major students), but without statistics it can't be "decision analytics".
reviews.comment_workload:
See the attached syllabus.
Final exam + group project (with presentation) + a few cases study (not too hard, just like an assignment. And you do it in a group).
